Q: When are disease -modifying antirheumatoid drugs usually prescribed?
A: Disease-modifying antir rheumatic drugs (DMARDs) are usually prescribed when symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis are moderate to severe and have not responded to a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) alone. The goal is to slow down the progression of the disease and prevent long-term joint damage. DMARDs are also often combined with corticosteroids to provide rapid relief of symptoms and prevent joint destruction. The decision to prescribe DMARDs and the choice of specific medications are made based on the severity of the disease, patient factors, and potential side effects of the medications. In some cases, DMARDs may be initiated earlier in the disease course if there is evidence of joint damage or widespread inflammation

Explanation: Methotrexate is a commonly used disease - modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. It is classified as a folic acid analogue and works by inhibiting the synthesis of dihydrofolate reductase, which is involved in the conversion of dihydrofolic acid to tetrahydrofolate. This leads to a decrease in the production of nucleotides, which are essential for cell division. Methotrexate also suppresses the immune system, reducing the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. It is usually prescribed at a low dose (7-15 mg per week) and requires regular monitoring for liver function and blood cell counts. Active tuberculosis: DMARDs can mask the signs and symptoms of tuberculosis, making it difficult to diagnose and treat this infection. prompt: How common is Huntington 's disease ( HD ) ?
watermarked_text:
How common is Huntington's disease ( HD )? How common is Huntington's disease ( HD )?
Huntington's Disease (HD) is a genetic disorder that is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. This means that if an individual inherits one copy of the mutated huntingtin gene from either parent, he or she will develop the disease. The prevalence of HD varies depending on the population being studied. It is estimated to affect approximately 1 in 10,000 people in the general population. However, the prevalence can be higher in certain populations with a higher rate of consanguinity, such as in some regions of North Africa and the Middle East. It is important to note that HD follows a Mendelian inheritance pattern, meaning that if one parent has HD, each child has a 50% chance of inheriting the disease-causing genetic mutation. natural_text: You may lose consciousness at the time of the head injury but this does not always happen . Classically , someone who develops an intracranial extradural haematoma loses consciousness at the time of the head injury and then has a ' lucid interval ' of a few hours after the head injury where they appear relatively well and normal . Later , they deteriorate and lose consciousness again as the haematoma forms . However , not everyone shows this classic pattern . If you do not lose consciousness after the initial head injury , or if you regain consciousness , you may experience drowsiness or a severe headache . You may also feel sick ( have nausea ) and/or be sick ( have vomiting ) . You may become confused and may develop weakness of an arm and/or a leg on one side of your body and/or speech difficulties . Sometimes a fit ( seizure ) can occur . Some people with an intracranial extradural haematoma can be talking one minute and appear relatively well and can then become very ill and lose consciousness the next . If you have a significant head injury , you should be taken to hospital urgently by ambulance . Anyone who loses consciousness at the time of a head injury should be taken to hospital straightaway . natural_text: Aspirin was used in the past for preventing strokes if you have AF but is not as effective as warfarin and is just as likely to cause problems . There are also new medicines that are as effective as warfarin and may have some advantages . These medicines are dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban . Warfarin can interact with some foods , alcohol and other medicines . Some of the newer anticoagulants ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) have less interaction with foods , alcohol and other medicines . If you take warfarin you will need regular blood tests ( INR tests ) to check how quickly your blood clots . Blood tests may be needed quite often at first but should become less often quite quickly . The aim is to get the dose of warfarin just right so your blood does not clot as easily as normal but not so much as to cause bleeding problems . Dabigatran , apixaban , edoxaban and rivaroxaban do not need regular blood tests .,

natural_text: The benefit of taking warfarin or one of the newer medicines is to reduce your risk of stroke . The main side - effect of these medicines is an increased risk of serious bleeding . Taking warfarin has a risk of bleeding and the dose of warfarin needs to be checked regularly . Therefore you will need to have regular blood tests if you are taking warfarin . If severe bleeding does happen , an injection of vitamin K will help to stop the effect of warfarin and so help to stop the bleeding . The newer medicines ( dabigatran , apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban ) also increase the risk of bleeding . However , they do not increase the risk of bleeding into the brain ( intracranial haemorrhage ) by nearly as much as warfarin . You will not need to have regular blood tests or change the dose of medicine you are taking with the newer medicines . Apixaban , rivaroxaban and edoxaban currently have no treatment to stop the effect of these medicines if you do have severe bleeding . Dabigatran can be reversed quickly with idarucizumab ( Praxbind ® ) . The newer agents do not stay in your body for as long as warfarin does . This means that any problem with bleeding disappears more quickly - usually in 12 - 24 hours .,

With most , the treatment aims are to stabilise your blood sugar and energy levels within your body . Some people with glycogen storage disorders who do not respond to nutritional supplements may occasionally need a liver transplant . People with glycogen storage disorders affecting their immune system may need to take regular antibiotic medication to protect against infection . What is the outlook ( prognosis ) of Haemochromatosis? Is it a serious disorder?
The outlook for individuals with hereditary haemochromatosis is generally favourable when the condition is diagnosed and treated early. With appropriate management, including regular phlebotomy and iron supplementation, the majority of patients can expect to live normal lives with no major health complications. However, if left untreated, hereditary haemochromatosis can lead to significant organ damage, heart problems, and increased risk of cancer. Iron overload can also cause symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, loss of libido, and skin pigmentation changes. If diagnosed at an early stage, patients can undergo regular phlebotomy to remove excess iron, and with good management, they can avoid or delay organ damage. Screening tests for tuberculosis are not just for people who work in health care or have a known exposure. They should be done for anyone who has risk factors for tuberculosis such as a weakened immune system, diabetes, close contact with someone with TB, or a history of TB in the past. TB screening tests include the Mantoux test (also known as the TB skin test) and blood tests such as the IGRA (Interferon-Gamma Release Assay). What is a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA )? 
TIA s are sometimes called mini-strokes because they produce similar symptoms to a stroke, but the symptoms are temporary and resolve within a short period of time. A TIA occurs when the blood supply to a part of the brain is temporarily reduced or stopped, which can last from a few minutes to a few hours.
What causes a transient ischaemic attack ( TIA )? 
The causes of TIA s are often similar to those of stroke. The most common cause is a blood clot that forms in a blood vessel in the neck or brain, blocking blood flow. Less commonly, a TIA can be caused by a dissolved blood clot that travels to the brain. Other rare causes include abnormalities in the blood vessels of the brain or neck, such as aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations ( AVMs ).

Common symptoms of a TIA include sudden weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg, usually on one side of the body. natural_text: A TIA causes symptoms similar to a stroke but the symptoms last for less than 24 hours . It is due to a temporary lack of blood to a part of the brain . In most cases , a TIA is caused by a tiny blood clot that becomes stuck in a small blood vessel ( artery ) in the brain . This blocks the blood flow and a part of the brain is starved of oxygen . The affected part of the brain is without oxygen for just a few minutes and soon recovers . This is because the blood clot either breaks up quickly or nearby blood vessels are able to compensate . Unlike a stroke , the symptoms of a TIA soon go . However , you should see a doctor urgently if you have a TIA , as you are at increased risk of having a full stroke . watermarked_text: Does everyone with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease need oxygen? Not everyone with COPD requires supplemental oxygen. Oxygen is given to patients based on the results of oxygen saturation monitoring and arterial blood gas tests. Oxygen may be indicated if the oxygen saturation level is consistently below 88% or if there is evidence of respiratory failure or hypoxemia. The goal of supplemental oxygen is to maintain oxygen saturation at 88-92%, as this is believed to reduce the risk of complications. Oxygen therapy can be delivered through nasal cannulae, face masks, or ventilators. Oxygen used in COPD therapy is generally considered low-flow oxygen, which delivers about 28-44% of the inspired gas. The standard concentration for oxygen therapy is 2L/min, but this can be adjusted based on individual patient needs. Caution must be exercised to avoid hyperoxia, which can lead to patient discomfort, preferential shunting, and potential oxidative injury. Here are some common causes: Benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH): BPH is a non-cancerous enlargement of the prostate gland, which can lead to an obstruction of urine flow and result in symptoms like frequent urination. Urinary tract infections (UTIs): UTIs can cause lower urinary tract symptoms such as burning sensation during urination, frequent urination, and urgency. Overactive bladder: An overactive bladder can cause a sudden and intense need to urinate, resulting in frequent trips to the bathroom. Prostatitis: Inflammation of the prostate gland can cause lower urinary tract symptoms, including pain during urination and erectile dysfunction in some cases. Medications: Certain medications, such as diuretics or antihistamines, can affect bladder function and cause lower urinary tract symptoms. Neurological disorders: Conditions like spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, or Parkinson's disease can affect the nerves that control bladder function and result in symptoms such as urinary retention or incontin

natural_text: There are various causes of LUTS . The more common causes include : An enlarged prostate gland . The prostate gland ( referred to from now on here as the prostate ) is situated around the neck of your bladder . When this gets bigger it can cause voiding symptoms . See the separate leaflet called Prostate Gland Enlargement for more details . Overactive bladder . As men ( and women ) get older , it is more common to develop bladder control problems . Your bladder may also be less able to store urine . This leads to you needing to pass urine more frequently and can even lead to leakage of urine at times ( incontinence ) . See the separate leaflet called Overactive Bladder Syndrome for more details . Water balance problems . As people get older , it becomes harder for the body to reduce the amount of urine that they pass at night . This leads to the need to pass urine more often at night . Therefore , at the age of 65 and over it can be normal to pass urine at least once a night . Other causes of LUTS include diabetes mellitus , urinary infections , bladder stones , prostate cancer , bladder cancer and neurological conditions ( eg , multiple sclerosis ) .,

The bed is then tilted ( head end up ) for up to 45 minutes while further recordings of your heart rate and blood pressure are taken . How is Duchenne muscular dystrophy ( DMD ) diagnosed?”
Duchenne muscular dystropy (DMD) is typically diagnosed through a combination of clinical evaluation, imaging tests, and genetic testing. The most common diagnostic approach involves conducting a physical examination to assess for signs of muscle weakness and testing for elevated levels of creatine kinase (CK) in the blood. Imaging tests such as muscle biopsies or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) may also be performed to confirm the diagnosis. Genetic testing is also used to identify specific gene mutations associated with DMD.

natural_text: The diagnosis may be suspected because of the child 's symptoms ( above ) . When looking for signs of DMD , it is important to watch the child running and getting up from the floor - the muscle weakness is more noticeable during these activities . Tests are needed before DMD can be diagnosed . The first step in making the diagnosis is a blood test . This tests for creatine kinase . Children with DMD always have a very high level of creatine kinase ( about 10 - 100 times normal ) . Therefore , if a child 's creatine kinase level is normal then DMD is ruled out . If the creatine kinase level is high , further tests are needed to see whether this is due to DMD or to some other condition . The next step in diagnosing DMD involves either a muscle biopsy and/or genetic tests : A muscle biopsy involves taking a small sample of a muscle , under local anaesthetic . The sample is examined under a microscope using special techniques to look at the muscle fibres and the dystrophin protein . Genetic tests are done using a blood sample . The DNA in the blood is tested to look at the dystrophin gene . This test can diagnose most cases of DMD .,

Physical therapy focuses on improving strength, balance, flexibility, and mobility. Occupational therapy helps individuals with cerebral palsy develop the skills necessary for daily living activities. Speech therapy can assist with speech and language development, as well as swallowing difficulties.
Medications may also be prescribed to help manage pain, spasticity, and other symptoms associated with cerebral palsy. In some cases, surgery may be recommended to alleviate muscle tightness, correct joint deformities, or reduce seizures.

natural_text: The outlook for sepsis can be good if it is diagnosed and treated early . However , without early treatment , between 10 and 50 people out of 100 will die , depending on the severity of sepsis . Older people tend to fare less well , especially if they have a long - term illness like diabetes or heart disease . Complications can include : Disseminated intravascular coagulation - this means the formation of blood clots in the small blood vessels throughout the body . Failure of the adrenal glands ( the glands that sit on top of the kidneys that produce adrenaline , steroids and other important body chemicals ) . Multiorgan failure - this means that several organs of the body stop working properly . These can include the heart , lungs and kidneys . As with any severe illness which needs intensive treatment in hospital , people recovering from sepsis may experience physical and psychological difficulties and these difficulties may last for several years . Physical problems may include feeling very tired , muscle weakness , feeling short of breath , chest pains , fluid swelling ( oedema ) , joint pains , poor appetite , disturbed vision , skin numbness or pins and needles , and frequent illness caused by further infections . Psychological difficulties may include feeling anxious , feeling low or depressed , nightmares , poor sleep , poor concentration and problems with memory .,

How does the occurrence of intravertaincular bleeding affect the long-term development and neurological outcome of premature babies? These questions are addressed in this article. Intraventricular bleeding is a major cause of neurological damage in preterm infants, occurring due to numerous factors such as immature blood vessels, oxygen free radical injury, haemodynamic changes, and concurrent infection. Early detection with ultrasound and prompt intervention with management of co-existing conditions are essential for improving outcomes. Effective preventive strategies, such as avoiding unnecessary prolonged use of mechanical ventilation and ensuring adequate perfusion, also play an important role in reducing intraventricULAR bleeding in preterm newborns. What is Intraventricular Haemorrhage in Babies?
Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) occurs when bleeding happens inside the ventricles of a newborn's brain. The term 'intraventricular' means inside the ventricles, while 'haemorrhage' refers to bleeding. This type of bleeding can lead to a buildup of blood within the ventricles, which can cause pressure on surrounding brain tissue. IVH is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention.

Some common causes of premature labor include: - Cervical insufficiency (a condition where the cervix does not stay closed properly) - Multiple pregnancies (twins, triplets, etc.) - Placental abnormalities - Infections - Preterm labor in a previous pregnancy - Smoking or substance abuse If the cause of premature labor is not addressed and managed properly, there is an increased risk of premature births in future pregnancies. Does pain in Ears during Flying happen to everyone?"
Ear pain during takeoff and landing is a common occurrence among flyers, but it doesn't affect everyone. The pressure changes that occur in the cabin during flight can cause ear discomfort or pain for some people. However, factors such as age, ear anatomy, and the presence of certain medical conditions can influence the likelihood of experiencing this symptom. People with a history of ear problems, such as ear infections or surgery, or those who have a narrow ear canal may be more prone to experiencing ear pain during flight. Additionally, young children and older adults may also be more susceptible due to developmental or anatomical differences in their ears. If you experience persistent or severe ear pain during flying, it is advisable to seek medical attention for further evaluation and treatment. Remember, it is always important to consult with a healthcare professional for personalized advice regarding your specific situation.

Why would I choose the progestogen - only pill?'
The progestogen-only pill, also known as the mini pill, is a form of contraception that only contains one hormone, progestogen. This pill works by thickening the cervical mucus and preventing it from meeting sperm. It also thins the lining of the uterus, making it difficult for a fertilized egg to implant. Here are a few reasons why you might choose the progetogen-only pill:
  1. Women who are breastfeeding: The progestogen in the pill can help suppress milk production, making it a good choice for mothers who are breastfeeding.
  2. Women who have had problems with blood clots or migraines: The proestogen-only pill has a lower risk of blood clots and migraines compared to combined hormonal contraceptives.
  3. Women with a history of hormonal imbalance: The pill can help regulate menstrual cycles and reduce the risk of ovarian cysts.
  4. Women who want a light or no period:
natural_text: Taking the POP does not interfere with sex . You can take it any time after childbirth , including immediately after delivery . You can take it when you are breastfeeding . It has a lower dose of hormone than the combined pill . The POP does not give you a higher risk of blood clots ( unlike the combined pill ) . It can therefore be used by some women who can not take the combined pill . For example , if you are aged over 35 and smoke , if you have migraines , or if you have high blood pressure .,

Severe acute respiratory syndrome, or SARS, is a viral respiratory illness caused by the coronavirus. It was first identified in China in 2002 and is characterized by symptoms such as fever, cough, and difficulty breathing. SARS is considered a severe illness with a high transmission rate, and it spread internationally through human-to-human contact. International travel and modern globalization facilitated its rapid spread across countries. What is Middle East respiratory syndrome ( MERS )? How concerned should we be about it? 
Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS) is a viral respiratory illness caused by the MERS coronavirus (MERS-CoV). It was first identified in Saudi Arabia in 2012 and has since caused outbreaks in several other countries in the region. MERS is spread through close contact with respiratory secretions from infected people, and there is evidence of person-to-person transmission in some cases. The virus can also be contracted from direct or indirect contact with camels or their products. The majority of MERS cases have been relatively mild, but a significant proportion (around 30%) have resulted in severe respiratory illness, kidney failure, and death. The overall mortality rate for MERS is about 35%. Although MERS-CoV does not currently pose a significant public health threat outside of the Middle East, the potential for international spread and the possibility of sustained human-to-human transmission warrant continued surveillance and research efforts. - See more at: http://www.sls

Frequent need to urinate, which may result in a burning sensation while urinating
Itching or irritation of the genital area
Discomfort or pain in the genital area
Swelling and redness in the genital area
In some cases, no symptoms may be present.

The treatment for non - gonococcal urethritis depends on the specific cause of the infection. Antibiotics are often prescribed to target the bacterial infection. This includes individuals who spend a lot of time outdoors in tick -infested areas, such as campers, hikers, and forestry workers. Those with occupations that involve working with infected animals, such as veterinary surgeons or laboratory workers, should also consider vaccination. People who have had a previous episode of tick - borne encephalitis are also at risk and should be immunised to prevent re-infection. Opioids have the potential to interact with other medications, which can affect how they work. Some common drug interactions with opioids include:

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect in which there is a narrowing of the aorta, the main artery that carries blood from the heart to the body. This narrowing obstructs the flow of blood, leading to symptoms such as high blood pressure in the upper body, weak or absent pulses in the lower body, fatigue, and shortness of breath. The most common type of coarctation of the aorta is preductal or infantile coarctation, which occurs before the development of the ductus arteriosus. Coa is often discovered in infancy or childhood, and symptoms may not appear in adulthood. Symptoms in adults may be present only during periods of increased physical activity, resulting in shortness of breath, intermittent cludication, and severe leg pain. natural_text: Endobronchial ultrasound - guided transbronchial needle aspiration is a special technique used to take samples of body tissue from inside the chest . It is also known as EBUS TBNA for short . The procedure is carried out using a special kind of bronchoscope . This is a thin flexible kind of ' telescope ' which passes through the mouth and into the airways . The bronchoscope ( often shortened to ' scope ' ) allows doctors to see inside the lungs and carry out the procedure . Endobronchial means from inside or within the bronchus . The bronchi ( the plural of bronchus ) are large tube - like airways . They take air from the windpipe ( trachea ) to the smaller airways , called the bronchioles . During the procedure ultrasound is used to help the doctor doing the test see the structures just outside the airways . This gives the test the first part of its name . The scope also contains a very fine needle . This needle is used to take samples of body tissue by pushing through the bronchus to the tissue on the other side . The needle holds the sample of tissue ; this is called aspiration . Transbronchial means across the bronchus , giving the name transbronchial needle aspiration .,

What are the symptoms of a transient ischaemic attack?  
The symptoms of a TIA, or mini-stroke, are similar to those of a stroke and can include sudden onset of: 
Numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg
Confusion or trouble with speech and language
Trouble with vision, such as blurry or double vision
Difficulty with walking or loss of balance
Severe headache
These symptoms typically last for a short time and go away on their own within an hour. It’s important to seek medical attention right away if you or someone else experiences these symptoms, as they could be signs of a more serious condition. 
How is a transient ishaemic attack diagnosed?  
To diagnose a TIA, your healthcare provider will rely on physical examination, medical history, and diagnostic tests. The key is to identify the cause of the symptoms quickly and begin treatment promptly. Tests for TIA may include: 
Imaging tests: such as CT or MRI scans, which can show bleeding or damage in the brain

Your dose of insulin may need to be increased or reduced depending on your blood glucose levels . If you are not sure then contact your GP or diabetes specialist nurse for advice . Ketones may appear in the blood and urine due to starvation or because of a lack of insulin . The presence of ketones in the urine may be a warning of diabetic ketoacidosis . Diabetic ketoacidosis is a serious complication of diabetes . Large amounts of ketones are released into the blood . The high level of ketones causes blood acidity , which is harmful to the body . How is Parkinson's disease ( PD ) diagnosed? Parkinson's disease is diagnosed based on medical history, a physical examination, and certain signs and symptoms. Doctors use a set of criteria established by the UK Parkinson's Disease Society Brain Bank to help confirm the diagnosis. These criteria consider the presence and severity of at least two of the following core symptoms : tremor, akinesia (difficulty moving), rigidity (stiffness), bradykinesia (slowness of movement), and postural instability. Some conditions can give ' Parkinsonism ' features - that is , symptoms similar to PD but caused by other conditions . For example , some medicines used to treat other conditions can cause side - effects which resemble symptoms of PD . Some rare brain disorders can also cause similar symptoms . Therefore , it is normal practice in the UK to be referred to a specialist if PD is suspected . The specialist will be used to diagnosing PD and ruling out other causes of the symptoms . The pathophysiology of PD -related dementia is complex and multifactorial, involving Lewy body pathology, cholinergic deficit, and cortical network disruption. If dementia occurs , it tends to develop in older people with PD ( aged over 70 ) . Early dementia in younger people with PD virtually never develops . The condition is associated with various medical conditions and can be caused by infections, autoimmune diseases, and allergic reactions. One of the most common causes is immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis, which occurs when the body forms abnormal proteins called immune complexes that deposit in the glomerular basement membrane and trigger inflammation. Glomerulonephritis can be acute or chronic, and its management depends on the underlying cause and severity of the disease. In many cases, treatment involves controlling the underlying condition, using medications to reduce inflammation, and managing symptoms such as high blood pressure and kidney failure. The duration and extent of treatment vary depending on the individual case, but with proper management, many people with glomerulonephritis are able to recover completely. Should I be concerned for Neck Lumps and Bumps? Yes, you should be concerned if you notice any neck lumps or bumps, especially if they are new or changing in size, shape or color. These can be a sign of a variety of conditions, such as infections, tumors or autoimmune diseases.
When should I see a doctor for a neck lump or bump? You should see a doctor if you notice a new lump or bump in your neck or if an existing lump is changing in size or color. It's also a good idea to seek medical attention if you have a fever, difficulty swallowing or breathing, persistent pain or numbness, or if you've recently been exposed to an illness. The doctor will need to examine the area and may perform additional tests to determine the cause of the lump or bump.
